design_audit.model_formula: dW/db = S * (L - eps_Sb + (1 + G/(Sb)) * eps_Yb); welfare gain from optimal subsidy via extrapolation
design_audit.selection_story: Model calibrates an education choice economy with liquidity constraints. Workers choose college vs no-college; college yields higher wages but requires upfront costs. Government provides tuition subsidy b financed by proportional income tax tau. Key sufficient statistics: S_hat (college attendance rate), eps_Sb (elasticity of S w.r.t. b), L_hat (liquidity constraint parameter from dS/da), ETI (elasticity of taxable income), tau_hat (tax rate). Welfare gain from moving b from current to optimal level is computed via numerical integration of dW/db.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Marginal welfare gain dW/db from increasing tuition subsidies at current policy
claim_object.treatment_concept: Tuition subsidy b relative to status quo b_hat=2 ($000s annual)
claim_object.estimand_concept: dW/db at b=b_hat, measuring net welfare effect of marginal subsidy increase incorporating fiscal externalities (eps_Yb) and liquidity constraints (L_hat)
claim_object.target_population: US economy calibrated to match aggregate education statistics (S_hat=0.388, tau_hat=0.23, etc.)

constraints.notes: Paper uses eps_Sb in {0.1, 0.2}, dsda in {0, 0.0021}. Key alternative model: NoFE (no fiscal externality) uses simpler formula dW/db = S*(L - (gamma1/(gamma1-S))*eps_Sb). Tables 3-8 present calibration and simulation results under different model variants.

canonical.notes: Calibration model -- no statistical inference. Results are deterministic given parameters.
